review.title: A Distance-based Paraconsistent Semantics for DL-Lite
review.abstract: DL-Lite is an important family of description logics. Recently, there is an increasing interest in handling inconsistency in DL-Lite as the constraint imposed by a TBox can be easily violated by assertions in ABox in DL-Lite. In this paper, we present a distance-based paraconsistent semantics based on the notion of feature in DL-Lite, which provides a novel way to rationally draw meaningful conclusions even from an inconsistent knowledge base. Finally, we investigate several important logical properties of this entailment relation based on the new semantics and show its promising advantages in non-monotonic reasoning for DL-Lite.

sections.heading: 2.2 Types and Features
sections.text: As we all know, models of a KB are often infinite and the number of models of a KB may be infinite. To characterize infinite models in a finite expression, two important terms, namely type and feature, are defined by [16] and [15] respectively for TBoxes and general KBs in a manner that has a signature. sections.heading: 3 Distance-based Semantics for Knowledge Bases
sections.text: This section defines minimal model characteristics of the KBs. Compared to the inconsistency of the TBoxes, we are not able to overcome all these inconsistencies that occur in KBs, because there are two additional cases: the inconsistency of the ABoxes and the inconsistency between TBoxes and ABoxes. Specifically, these inconsistencies occur in the concepts, between the assertions and role assertions, between the assertions and inclusions, even between a single inclusion and a single assertion. Example 3 Let K = ({P −)) will be a KB (see [15]) and the role assertions. He concludes that K is not consistent and therefore does not exhibit model characteristics i.e., ModF (K) =. In order to deal with these various inconsistencies in a uniform way, we adopt the technique of compressing minimal model types in order to construct them directly over the characteristics.

sections.heading: 4 Properties of Distance-based Semantics
sections.text: In general, most existing semantic thought patterns are much weaker than the classical semantic perceptions that exist.

sections.heading: 5 Related Works
sections.text: In this section, we compare our scenario with existing para-consistent approaches in DL-Lite or other DLs. Existing model-centric approaches to inconsistency handling are usually based on types of extended inconsistency of tolerable semantics, such as quadrivalent description logic of [18] and quasi-classical description logic of [12]. Compared to them, our distance-based semantics works on classical interpretations, but can still draw more meaningful and reasonable logical conclusions. For example, quadrivalent DL-Lite, modus ponens, modus tollens and disjunctive syllogism are no longer valid. Taking the Penguin KB for example, we cannot draw the intuitive conclusions that the swallowpig is a bird and can fly under quadrivalent semantics (with the material inclusion interpretation [18]). In contrast, quasic DLs can present basic argumentation rules, but they may be inconsistent if they are too much semantic.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we have presented a model-based framework for dealing with inconsistencies in DL-Lite by introducing distances across types of characteristics for CBs. Within this framework, we define a kind of semantics (so-called distance-based semantics) that characterizes a kind of cautious dependency relationship that is paraconsistent, non-monotonous, and has the splitting property. A characteristic of distance-based engagement is that it largely maintains consistency. Furthermore, our model-based framework takes into account both minimal semantic changes and the rule of "majority consideration" in syntax. In this sense, our approach is a natural combination of qualitative and quantitative approaches. As a result, our scenario is finer-grained compared to previous approaches to paraconsistent reasoning. Although distance-based semantics presented in this paper is based on classical semantics (general divalence-based semantics), we can build on a semantics based on a semantics based on two-value.

referenceMentions.context: The DL-Lite [1] is a family of lightweight description logics (DLs), the logical foundation of OWL 2.
The first one is based on the assumption that inconsistencies are caused by erroneous data and thus, they should be removed in order to obtain a consistent KB ([2, 3, 4, 5, 6]).

[11] present the Belnap’s four-valued semantics of DLs where two additional logical values besides “true” and “false” are introduced to indicate contradictory conclusions.
[12, 13] present the Hunter’s quasi-classical semantics of DLs whose strong semantics strengthens the inference power of four-valued semantics.

Recently a distance-based semantics presented by [14] has been proposed to deal with inconsistent KBs in propositional logic.
To overcome these difficulties, in this paper we first use the notion of features [15] and introduce a distance-based semantics for paraconsistent reasoning with DL-Lite.
In addition, features also generalize the notion of types for TBoxes [16] to general KBs.

Example 3 Let K = ({∃P ⊑ ⊥}, {∃P (a)}) be a KB (see [15]) and Σ = {P, a, 1}.
We argue that this adoption can not only uniformly deal with all inconsistencies but also overcome difficulty of defining distance over pairs of features (see [15]).

Furthermore, distance-based semantics also embodies the idea of “majority vote consideration” (see [14]), that is, conclusions must hold more argument for them, for resolving contradictions so that the results are more stable.
For this reason, we need hereditary aggregation functions to really guarantee the validity of the splitting property (see [14]).

Recently, there is an increasing interest in handling inconsistency in DL-Lite as the constraint imposed by a TBox can be easily violated by assertions in ABox in DL-Lite.
